openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/s.message: The usual spelling is 'ICMPv6' ('v' is lower)
In Neutron API, ipv6-icmp is preferred for ICMPv6. "icmpv6" is a legacy though we don't have a plan to drop it soon, but for a new code, I would suggest to use 'ipv6-icmp'.
Is there a case where cleaned_data['ip_protocol'] is not a string?
Yes, see the failed test case on the previuos patch.
I see. ip_protocol is Integer field, so perhaps the cleaned data is an integer. Thanks.
This is a constant, so I think tuple() is enough. This is just my preference.

I didn't know set is faster.

semantically I am not sure what is correct as it is a constant and developers take care of the values.

I am okay with it.
Set is faster and more correct semantically.

This is fine, but in an almost-merged change to neutron master branch, 'icmp', 'icmpv6' and 'ipv6-icmp' are all accepted for IPv6, and will result in a rule with 'ipv6-icmp' as the protocol.  We decide to standardize on that to not cause confusion.
I don't think this conversion is needed.

There is more than one way to add an icmp rule, not just the "all icmp" option in horizon. I think it's nice to be consistent and always do the right thing.

(I also think that this should actually be handled on the Neutron side, but that's beside the point.)
For IPv4, only 'icmp' is valid, the others aren't, and IMHO should raise an error as they are invalid.

I haven't understood what is consistent.

If a user specify some IPv6 related protocol like ipv6-icmp, icmpv6, and 58, I wonder the user tries to create IPv6 rule. There may be a case where the user just forget to set IPv6 CIDR rather than specifying IPv4 CIDR before clicking the submit button.

IMHO it is better to show an error message that the protocol and IP version do not match.

But that's inconsistent with what we do in the IPv6 case then. The way I did it, it's symmetric -- no matter which kind of icmp you specify, it will always be changed to the correct one for the CIDR you specified. Why should IPv4 icmp be "special" and be automatically changed to ipv6-icmp, and not the other way around? Why should one raise and error, and not the other?
question: Would we like to convert a numeric IP protocol into a symbol? We don't do this for other protocol like tcp,  so I wonder we don't need to do this for consistency.

We could easily do this in a way that did not change from string form to int form.  For example:

    if netaddr.IPNetwork(cidr).version == 6:
      if (str(cleaned_data['ip_protocol']) == '1':
        cleaned_data['ip_protocol'] = 58
      elif str(cleaned_data['ip_protocol']).lower() == 'icmp':
        cleaned_data['ip_protocol'] = 'icmpv6'

Would that alleviate your concern?  I don't see the need for a general text-to-int conversion table, but if we do decide we need one here perhaps we can leverage the socket library instead of neutron-lib.

    import socket
    table = {num:name[8:] for name,num 
             in vars(socket).items() 
             if name.startswith("IPPROTO")}
    
The contents of 'table' are now:

{0: 'HOPOPTS',
 1: 'ICMP',
 2: 'IGMP',
 4: 'IPIP',
 6: 'TCP',
 8: 'EGP',
 12: 'PUP',
 17: 'UDP',
 22: 'IDP',
 29: 'TP',
 41: 'IPV6',
 43: 'ROUTING',
 44: 'FRAGMENT',
 46: 'RSVP',
 47: 'GRE',
 50: 'ESP',
 51: 'AH',
 58: 'ICMPV6',
 59: 'NONE',
 60: 'DSTOPTS',
 103: 'PIM',
 255: 'RAW'}
 

As a general rule I think we should definitely not try autoconverting for all protocols.  I say this because there is an unassigned range and (outside this ICMP use case) someone might need to assert a rule for a numeric IP protocol that has no text representation, because it was invented by some vendor.
BTW, don't we need to move the logic added here outside of the if clause? The new logic is also needed for remote group case.

I'm fine with Nate's suggestion, and agree we should only do it for ICMP as it's a special case that we've had to work around in the Neutron API.  We just need to make sure we use the correct values:

'1'/'icmp' for IPv4
'58'/'ipv6-icmp' for IPv6

The Neutron API can handle mismatches, but might as well do it right.

After looking at the implementation of this form in detail, the following cases should happen:

- When "Custom ICMP Rule" or "All ICMP" is selected, 'icmp' is populated as ip_protocol here, so it needs to be converted into 'ipv6-icmp' if IPv6. (This is required to support both of IPv4 and IPv6 in a same menu.)
- When "Other protocol" is selected, a user can specify an integer value as ip_protocol. In this case, a warning to users looks better rather than converting it automatically.

Note that a user cannot specify string representations as ip_protocol in the current horizon implementation. This is different from the neutron API behavior. Someone can improve the horizon implementation future but this never happens now.

Akihiro, when you said "convert into a symbol" did you mean make a constant for it?  I am unfamiliar with "symbol" in the Python context.

If you did mean "make a constant" then I agree it's unnecessary.

So I think in essence you're saying we don't need this "cleaning"?  If so I would agree with that, I don't think it's required just seems to be trying to make a better user experience by not raising an error.

Depending on that we can then add tests, since otherwise an invalid call will just get cleaned.

Thanks Brain and Nate.

"symbol" I mean is a string representation like "tcp", "icmp". In other word, "string" (tcp) vs "integer" (6).

This patch introduces protocol number auto-conversion to string representation only for 'icmp'. If we introduce it only for icmp, it will bring inconsistency. This is my concern.

I see two routes on this:
(1) to introduce auto-conversion for all known IP protocol.  (I am not sure it is a good idea to have a copy of neutron-lib constants for this conversion.)
(2) not to convert protocol numbers to strings.

If we go to (1), this patch can go as-is and other stuffs can be added as a follow-up patch. If (2), the conversion in this patch needs to be dropped.

Thought?

Thanks for sharing your thoughts. I agree Nate's suggestion.

I forgot the main point of handling ICMPv6 properly and seems to concern the auto-conversion from integer to string too much.
I think this is superfluous,the error message has been processed above.

Done.

I noticed this after pushing patch set 10, but I didn't update the patch soon.  I would like to hear opinions on the preferred approach from reviewers.

It seems we have a consensus on the direction, so I updated the patch.

I realize this comes from the openstack file, but this regex just seems odd. Why would they have [a] there? This would be a character set that matches only 'a'. If the intent it to match .yml or .yaml files, this doesn't do that. In that case, the regex should be:
".*\.ya?ml"

Example:
$ ls -1
a.yaml
b.yml
cyaml
$ find . -type f -regex '.*.y[a]ml' -print
./cyaml
./a.yaml
$ find . -type f -regex '.*\.ya?ml' -print
./b.yml
./a.yaml

Question to reviewers: should this just be --type to match the "Type" column in the output when using 2.23+? Not a big deal, but it's a bit redundant/wordy when you're doing migration-list to specify --migration-type, just doing migration-list --type seems easier.

The python binding API method kwarg needs to stay migration_type though to avoid colliding with the type reserved word.

Question to reviewers: should this just be --type to match the "Type" column in the output when using 2.23+? Not a big deal, but it's a bit redundant/wordy when you're doing migration-list to specify --migration-type, just doing migration-list --type seems easier.

The python binding API method kwarg needs to stay migration_type though to avoid colliding with the type reserved word.

Yahbut, if someday we need e.g. an "instance type" as well, --migration-type X --instance-type Y reads better than --type X --instance-type Y

Explicit is better than implicit?

Autocomplete for the typing-challenged?

Takashi has a good point about precedent and consistency with other --*-type options in nova CLI. (1) and (2) that Andrey pointed out are clearly why I was thinking about this in the first place. And now that Andrey mentions OSC, I looked up to see if --key-type is in OSC and there is an open change for it and I made the same comment there:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/577768/7/openstackclient/compute/v2/keypair.py@59

I do like the idea that migrating from nova CLI to OSC would be more seamless by being consistent in the option names, but I would get too hung up on that since anyone migrating their scripts is going to have to do the work of figuring out what the OSC command structure and options are anyway. Meaning it's never going to be a straight clean cut-over to OSC for users.

So I'm OK either way - using --migration-type for consistency in nova CLI, or using --type for the reasons Andrey pointed out. We could ask for Dean Troyer's opinion if we need someone else to weigh in.
Agree with Takashi, '--migration-type' is clearly and friendly for me.

I agree with Takashi's point that all current CLI arguments have 'prefixes' (i.e --key-type, --backup-type, --console-type), but at the same time I see several pros for using just `--type`:

1) it is much simpler for typing, harder to omit the typo == more user-friendly

2) as Matt already mentioned, it is also matching what users will see at the output (at least for 2.23+)

3) I do not know when it will happen, but someday novaclient's CLI will be deprecated in favor of OSC. In terms of this process, as less inconsistency between OSC and novaclient's CLI will be, as fewer users will fill uncomfortable about the switch. Most OSC commands (for all services) use `--type` argument when it is possible (i.e `openstack server backup create $NAME --type $BACKUP_TYPE`, `openstack volume create $NAME --type $VOLUME_TYPE`, `openstack policy create $POLICY_FILENAME --type $POLICY_TYPE`)


Imo, there are more pros than cons and it would be nice to use `--type` everywhere (i.e for 2.0 and update keypairs, backups CLI as well) but the current approach works for me as well (since it is consistent to what we had before)

IMO, it is okay because '--migration-type' is clearer in terms of what is specified in the option.
And I know another example. The '--key-type' option can be specified in adding a keypair and the 'Type' column is shown in output of the 'nova keypair-list' command.

  usage: nova keypair-add [--pub-key <pub-key>] [--key-type <key-type>]
                          [--user <user-id>]
                          <name>

  stack@devstack-master:/opt/devstack$ nova keypair-list
  +-------+------+-------------------------------------------------+
  | Name  | Type | Fingerprint                                     |
  +-------+------+-------------------------------------------------+
  | TEST1 | ssh  | 14:7a:7b:e5:31:34:33:48:c3:35:df:52:b2:28:ab:2d |
  +-------+------+-------------------------------------------------+

This is an area where I have preferred to use context for what exactly --type means, and most of OSC is like that.  There are some glaring inconsistencies there that I would love to fix, then network came along and is complicated enough that context of the command is not always enough in some cases.

I would stay consistent with nova CLI for nova commands and OSC for OSC commands.  I think that is the 'least surprising' thing to do for users.

In the end for me consistency and user expectations should be the guiding factor.  Reasonable people often disagree on exactly what that is...
Agree with Dean I think it makes most sense to stay consistent with other things in python-novaclient here.

Oh yes

 nova migration-list --migration-type migration

I would almost say it's worth renaming this (you'll obv have to translate it between CLI and API).
@Eric: I guess it should be fixed at nova's API side...

This https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678593/ tries to just clarify the docs. If we want to go a step further and add a translation shim for specifying cold-migration -> migration, then I can do that as well. The question would be, does the CLI actually start validating the given values (it doesn't today, nor does the API json schema [1]) and if so, does it accept both "cold-migration" and "migration" (I'd think so yes since people might already be familiar with filtering non-live cold migrations in the API using "migration").

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/781f47b243f1924087b60fd0b840f7f1c67c96c4/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/migrations.py#L27

No, this is exactly my point. What is considered good API design is *not* necessarily good CLI design. Selecting from a list of migration types, one of which is "migration", is poor UX.

Again, not downvoting, just expressing an opinion.
I'd prefer to do that in a follow up so I don't lose the +2s on this change.
--migration-type migration? are they not all migrations? what does migration mean here as a value? haha, how confusing

To restate, I would prefer if the token were actually cold-migration here, and translated to 'migration' under the covers if that's what's necessary.

Won't block on it, though.

Can we add a description for this (e.g. migration is cold migration type), otherwise it is confusing.
Unless it is 'live-migration', it is a scene of 'cold migration'.

[See comment below for background on this paragraph]

There is a larger multi-cycle goal of completing the transition from project-specific command line clients and Python libraries to OpenStackClient and the OpenStack SDK.  Generally there is no dependency between these two components, they could happen in parallel and one command at a time.

* Bring OSC commands to parity with the project CLIs.  This is adding resources and options so the same operations and capabilities are available in OSC.
* Replace OSC's use of project Python client libraries with OpenStackSDK.  This implies that SDK has the required support and is an external dependency.

[Reword the above paragraph as it is no longer the introduction to the goal, just to the work items below. This is what I want to say but my morning-brain is making it awkward to get written...]

The following have been identified as areas needing attention, and are not exclusive, but the areas where people have already committed to doing the work or at least have performed some analysis on the work required.

There are two parts overall to the work in OSC:

* Reach parity so project CLIs can be deprecated (what Keystone did a while back)
* Replace the use of project client Python libs with OpenStack SDK

The second bullet has an implied requirement of the SDK having parity that has been discussed as a possible goal in the past.

Of all of this work, the only hard dependency here is that the SDK has to have required support before OSC can cut over to using it, and that is only at a per-command level, not the entire REST API.

I think for this goal we need to be a bit broader as Lance suggests because there is/may be plenty of work in other projects that can also happen.  My personal priority has always been to eliminate python-glanceclient first due to the number of unique dependencies it has.

We can also include statements about tracking and supporting the OSC plugins that may also have project-specific CLIs.  This work would not take place in the OSC repos but would still be inclusive of more of the community and work toward the goal.

Getting to 2.72 (latest in Stein) is going to be tough for the compute API in Train if only 1-2 people are working on this, and it's then definitely less of a community-wide goal if lots of community non-nova people are working on filling the gaps in the compute API support in OSC.

What I have suggested several times when talking about this is hitting some widely-used older release baseline, e.g. mitaka or newton at this point.

The max compute API version in mitaka was 2.25 and looking at:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/compute-api-microversion-gap-in-osc

You'll see there are plenty of gaps between 2.1 and 2.25 support in OSC. So a reasonable goal for *nova* would be to have feature parity up through mitaka, which sounds like an extremely low bar, but it's also something that should be achievable, which I think we'll need as part of this effort.

If you want to go further, for the compute API, 2.38 was the max in newton and newton is our current (newest) EOL branch.

For other projects like ironic and designate that have always had OSC plugins and therefore more current CLIs, setting a goal for mitaka or newton parity doesn't make sense, so I'm not sure what the goal would be for those projects.

What I wanted is somehow to describe in details, what is really required. This is a never-ending catch game, where service adds new microversions and CLI need to make use of them. So we might want to give some base.

I'm not sure what this is saying. What is "development stage"? I think you're just saying it's been stable for several years and some projects, e.g. keystone, have already migrated from their legacy CLI (python-keystoneclient) to OSC. And other projects have always used OSC plugins for CLI, like ironic, designate and placement.

As noted below, this could also be phrased in terms of using the SDK for session management and getting all of the common features while still having the Python API outside of the SDK.  It would be the project's choice, with the community preference for including official APIs in the SDK directly.

If projects have to make a choice, we should provide guidance. So if I'm working on nova which already has a huge OSC gap in functionality, would the recommendation to be to use the existing python-novaclient python SDK for filling the OSC CLI gaps (since OSC already uses novaclient as an SDK)? Or would the recommendation be to get the openstacksdk compute API support up to date first and then have OSC use that to fill the CLI gaps (I very much assume the former).

But that scenario might not be true for other projects who already have a lot of support in the SDK and can rely on that for fleshing out the CLI.

For nova, I think it's going to be one or the other (SDK work or OSC CLI work) and we have to set a goal for an older release parity (mitaka or newton).

Hopefully it is clear that nova lacks the resources to bring osc to parity in one release even without porting to SDK. So since this is a long-term thing, my preference would be to do it in the way that doesn't throw away work, which is what happens if we catch up using novaclient and then start porting to sdk. So I would like to see:

- An initial effort to set up the framework for osc-nova [1] via SDK if that's not already there. That framework will obviously need to live side-by-side with the existing novaclient back end for "a while".
- Any new work in novaclient mirrored in osc-nova in the sdk-using way, even if it means porting an existing chunk of osc-nova from novaclient to sdk [2].
- In the background, existing novaclient-using pieces of osc-nova ported to, and parity gaps filled with, sdk-ness "as resources allow" [3].

[1] by which I mean openstackclient/compute, unless we care to make a separate osc-nova (osc-compute?) project
[2] obviously this is not an absolute mandate; if it turns out to be huge for a specific feature, we can have an exception process to defer
[3] which is obviously the big thing: who's going to do the work here? Like getting rid of mox [4], this is likely to be a thankless task where somebody does a lot of hard work and then watches their patches sit in limbo because reviewers are focused on fancy features.
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:openstack/nova+branch:master+topic:bp/mox-removal-stein

There is no one-size-fits-any for this, there are too many variables, which is why I am trying to phrase things in terms of objectives and let the projects sort out their right path.

For nova, it could be one or the other, or can be both, as needed.  These are not exclusive and both can be done one command at a time.

In the case of novaclient, we could create a list of all the "gaps" between that and OSC. That list could be broken into bite-size chunks that could be worked on one-by-one until there are no more gaps. While that is happening, nova should have a policy of no changes to novaclient without also making the corresponding change to OSC.

Is this saying that there's no need to deprecate/remove the non-cli part of the python-*client libraries? Should e.g. the nova service continue using the python-ironicclient library to talk to ironic, or should it be using openstacksdk to talk to ironic?

A goal here is that all CLI stuff is handled by OSC. While python-Xclient may still exist, it should not deliver own CLI implementation (except plugins to OSC for services not included in OSC natively, and those plugins should ideally use SDK)

The way it reads to me, this goal just talks about the CLI. I would expect a separate goal at some point to talk about swapping out project X's use of python-Yclient to in favor of openstacksdk to talk to service Y. In other words, the goal of this goal :) is not (yet) to be able to get rid of python-Yclient entirely. But it's a step in that direction.

Hmm, why just 'image'? i.e. is the goal for the entire community to work on getting image API / CLI parity in the openstacksdk and OSC CLI so python-glanceclient can be deprecated? Remember that other projects are also using python-glanceclient as an SDK (like nova, cinder, heat) so deprecating python-glanceclient means those projects need to either (1) re-write their internal image API client code to use direct REST (which is fine and probably the best thing long-term anyway but is a lot of work) or (2) start using the openstacksdk in service projects like nova, and it was my understanding (albeit from several years ago) that that was not recommended because of dependency and performance creep with using the SDK in the service projects (that was maybe true back at the first Vancouver summit for Liberty when I last remember talking about this).

The situation with the SDK and assumptions made about dependencies is flipped from where it was several years ago.  Monty has committed to keeping the dependencies clean enough so dependencies that servers and python-*client libraries assume are OK are not present on client-side installations (oslo.config I'm looking at you, among others).  With that the SDK should be usable in both contexts.  Of course, server-side usage is always up to the server side teams.

just 'image' because if we list here everything - we will definitely not achieve it for train. I am ok to put compute here as well, but this does not mean we have people who will implement this.

I have explicitly rephrased it everywhere, that goal is not to deprecate individual clients, but to remove standalone CLI implementation from them. They might still exist and deliver OSC plugins, but not own CLI stuff. Can it still be misunderstood?

def do_ceph_mon_modify(cc, args):
    controller = vars(args).get('controller', None)
    patch = utils.args_array_to_patch("replace", args.attributes[0])
    patch.append({
        'op': 'replace', 'path': '/controller', 'value': controller
    })

    # Obtain the host whose ceph monitor we want to modify.
    ihost = ihost_utils._find_ihost(cc, controller)
    ceph_mon = cc.ceph_mon.list(ihost.uuid)[0]

    changes = dict(v.split("=", 1) for v in args.attributes[0])
    if changes.get('ceph_mon_gib', None) and \
            changes['ceph_mon_gib'] != getattr(ceph_mon, 'ceph_mon_gib'):

        for ceph_mon in cc.ceph_mon.list():
            cc.ceph_mon.update(ceph_mon.uuid, patch)
        _print_ceph_mon_list(cc)
        print("\nNOTE: ceph_mon_gib for both controllers are changed.")
    else:
        ceph_mon = cc.ceph_mon.update(ceph_mon.uuid, patch)
        _print_ceph_mon_show(ceph_mon)

Better write it like:
* Magnum will set in all CTs and NGTs mark_for_deletion: True and obsolete: True
* Magnum will delete all CTs and NGTs that are not referenced by any Cluster or NG
* After any Cluster/NG delete magnum will try to delete the corresponding CT/NGT if it's not refernced elsewhere.

My thought here is that it is really an all or nothing on the delete.  So only the parent really needs to be marked for delete instead of updating all of the versions.  At any given time only the latest version is not obsolete already.  So when a delete happens it could simply mark the latest to obsolete and mark the parent as "marked_for_delete". The check for the actual db template clean up can use the parent as we wouldn't want the parent to be deleted until all the versions are.

My major objection is for this point. Cluster template is not suitable to manage upgrade scenarios (it should be purely used to create cluster). Upgrade scenrios should be managed by drivers.

From my understanding the desire is for the ClusterTemplates to simply communicate "what" has changed between 2 versions. The versioning provides a way to do this.  cluster-upgrade could be generated to use no templates at all. Like this:

cluster-upgrade clusterA --coe-version 1.2

Templates just give something for the operator to maintain and easily track the versions. If clusterA is created with templateX v1 and then coe-version is updated to 1.2 then the template become templateX v2. So the upgrade command could be:

cluster-upgrade ClusterA

To magnum, the comparison of ClusterA attributes to templateX v2 would give a difference of coe-version=1.2. So info sent to the driver would be exactly the same as with cluster-upgrade --coe-version 1.2.  It is just a simplified way to describe the difference instead of the user having to figure out themselves the difference between versions. It is calculated for them.  The underlying implementation of how an upgrade remains the same in both cases. Templates are just another way to feed the parameters to a command.

Templates just provide a simplified way for operators to maintain templates for cluster creation and life cycle operations.  They are short hand way to describe a set of attributes.  They are in no way required, they just make life easier for the user/operator.

I would argue that using template in this way is very confusing. Basically, here is what you proposed:

* A cluster is upgraded from template version x to template version y

This is confusing because template version x/y contains a large amount of attributes that are irrelevant to upgrade (i.e. node_count). As a result, the upgrade operation will look very complicated from outside (most of the people are not Magnum developers so they don't understand how an upgrade is implemented and how the set of attributes are being handled).

Here is what I proposed:

* A cluster is upgraded from driver version x to driver version y

I think this is more intuitive because driver version x/y contains only the attributes that are relevant to upgrade (coe, distro, image, ....). It satisfies all the use cases you wanted (maintain and track versions, simplified way to describe the diff between versions, simplified way for cluster creation), while improves the maintainability of upgrade. I believe operations will appreciate a better way to describe upgrade.
OK. I agree with this. Let's pull irrelevant attributes (i.e. node_count) out of cluster template. Then, I am happy to revisit this proposal.
I mean that is why I lean to separated data model for templates and drivers.

I still think in our case the cluster template is the suitable piece to manage upgrades. They have fields not related to the drivers - things related to the infrastructure (dns servers, certificates, etc), and things related to the 'recommended' setup of the clusters, including fields that are outside the driver definition.

As an example in our setup most people rely on our public templates as this is our way to pass the recommended configuration - which suits 90% of the cases up to now. We recently changed our public cluster templates to have docker_volume_size == 0 (no cinder volume for docker images). If there would be versioning it would have allowed users to upgrade their clusters to this new config without recreating them... without it they had to recreate them from scratch.

My personal view is to upgrade clusters based on the attributes only(Yes, using template as a medium would help in using it). With v1 proposed approach was making more sense where ct and clusters were more coupled.

It would be good if all the attributes can be listed in the spec which would be used during upgrade. May be that is out of scope but That's the major use case i can see here for which template versioning is out.

Cluster template is state A, cluster is created and is at state A1(Most of the parameter are changed while creating cluster so keeping reference not making any sense)
Upgrade cluster by passing attributes(or cluster template). Judge Upgrade based on Current State A1 and passed Attributes, if judgement passed upgrade to State A2.

Then this means cluster upgrade is not dependent on Template versioning but what i can get from etherpad and other discussion is that template versioning is required for cluster upgrade. Did i get somthing wrong?

Also upgrade can be done to any version so reference of latest can be updated in the spec.

You are exactly right. Template versioning is not really required for cluster upgrade. It could be done without it. The request though was to provide a easy way for operators to represent the upgrade and track templates. That is how this spec was created. I think template versioning would be useful but i don't think it is really required for upgrades.  I think that is where this review has gotten sidetracked.  We need to address what we want around upgrade and cluster updates. Then we can see if this the improved template version tracking is still needed on top of that for operators. If not we can lower the priority on this. I think it is still useful, but i think we should decouple it from being required.

Agreed, in my opinion the upgrade command doesn't need templates at all. Templates and template versions are just one way for the user to describe to the command what changes are desired. Whether that those are direct parameters passed in like: 

cluster-upgrade clusterA --coe_version=1.2

Or latest template:

cluster-upgrade ClusterA

Or targeted template

cluster-upgrade ClusterA --target_template_version 3


Those are just examples, not what i'm suggesting the options be. It should be up to cluster-upgrade to determine what options it wants.  Templates with versioning just adds an additional way to pass the set of changes. Templates are not required for upgrade, they just make the user experience better for operators and users.

This will be a new check?

Essentially, yes. It would be required for (a) https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/942fa495b611c688b12ee8913799a3f6521af19b/magnum/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L113 to work without a trust in place (otherwise Magnum cannot retrieve the cluster template/cluster associated with that user) and (b) for granting that user access to the certificates for the cluster.
These are some examples, we shouldn't take action based on cluster template or cluster attributes.

Why not? The cluster template's attributes tell us if the cluster user needs to access APIs other than Magnum's certificate API, or not. And the certificate API is taken care of by the mechanism in (1).
Sorry, I should have removed that after our IRC discussion last week. It's the bit that we agreed is not really neccessary.

We can't be limited by that. It's like a heuristic. We need maybe another field to define the level of power that is given to a cluster. Or just a general option in the configuration that will apply for all clusters.

Well, those two cases need a trust assigned to the cluster user. Without it they won't work. I agree on having a configuration option to generally enable/disable this in addition to that (added that now).

swift/obj/replicator.py.message: Interesting... so this case wasn't getting handled before?

This changes the behavior quite a bit.

Before this change there was a default timeout of 60 seconds for the whole request - that is connection setup and reading the response read. It didn't matter which part was slow; might be the connection setup that took 50 seconds and reading the response took only 5 seconds, or vice versa.

With this change applied, the connection setup time is hard limited to 5 seconds, and the response read itself is 60 seconds.

This might create problems with slow peers, and operators can't increase the 5 second conn_timeout setting. This sounds like possible trouble to me.

I would prefer to keep the existing behavior, and because direct_get_suffix_hashes is only used in obj/replicator.py it should be fine to refactor that method a bit.
Same as above regarding the timeouts.

before we didn't care what the reponse code was of this REPLICATE, now if it is not 2xx we skip to the exception handler, which means we don't delete handoff objs.

If I wrap this in a try/except DirectClientException to suppress any exception (i.e. revert to old behaviour), then I see no unit tests failing :/ But the unit tests always mock http connection to return 200, so it seems we have no coverage for the exception case.
ok. before we handled bad responses here and then did continue'd with loop, now we get an exception, handle at end of clause and continue with loop

hmmm, I'm concerned about how this change impacts remote replication in particular...

before, if resp != 2xx, we would proceed through lines 475-482, now we skip them and go to the exception handler, which means we do not update synced_remote_regions.

So, we successfully sync'd object to remote region, but the follow-up REPLICATE failed (remote node may not have updated its hashes pickles) - do we really want to change behaviour so that now we will sync the objects again to another node in the remote region? I'm not sure how that helps - the second REPLICATE to the second node in the remote region could also fail, so there's no guaranteed benefit to syncing to another node.
ok. Timeouts on REPLICATE still get handled here.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The change does more than just syncing in ``charms.ceph`` changes.

While I dug and found out why, and agree with your change, it will be more obvious for the next passer by if there is a short explanation of why this change was necessary.
There are more RPM platforms than those using dnf and yum like the SUSE ones.

Indeed but the scope of the change is to enable us to distinguish between dnf and yum blends of fedora/centos/rhel, obviously without breaking any platforms.

User can still narrow down using AND conditions with dnf/yum, probably most will also add "platform:redhat" in
order to limit the coverage.

Still, i see no reason why the same logic would not apply
to other platforms. I just didn't know what to add to others.

So, the problem you are solving is that bindep does not allow ">" for the OS, correct?

I find dnf and yum as names for platforms confusing.

Adding version comparison would be a major change, not only to develop but also to test.

Well, the cause if the use of "platform" terms, probably there for historic reasons. In the end a term like atoms or tags would probably have being less confusing.
this isn't true in the case of RHEL>7 (assuming CentOS>8) see other comment for upstream documentation.

In summary, the concern is that the above turns into

 python-devel [platform:redhat !platform:fedora !platform:centos-8 !platform:rhel-8]
 python3-devel [platform:fedora platform:centos-8 platform:rhel-8]

when we consider rhel+centos8?  

The main problem being, we have to filter out all the "new" (python3) distros from the "platform:redhat" match.

Additionally, should there be a rhel/centos-9 this would need updating?

---

I certainly see why you've come to dnf/yum as the differentiator.  I agree with others though that this feels like an odd implementation thing to switch on, that we will have to live with forever.

I think I'd prefer to see this named "redhat-python2" and "redhat-python3".  I feel like this would abstract things.  It may be the case that the easiest way to define those variables in bindep is like this with a yum/dnf switch.  but it leaves us the option of defining them some other way too -- even just hard-coding lists of distros in bindep if need be.
This could be amended now that you've added more distros.
Done
Might be good to also add tests for the latter three cases, but I don't think we need to hold up this patch for that, I'd also do this in a followup myself if needed.
Done

README.rst.message: I guess you mean "... where python2 or python3 ..." instead of 2x python3?

I'm concerned that these "global" labels are only implemented for red hat distros and osx. At the very least we should document that limitation.

How difficult would it be to add base-py* rules for all of the distros currently supported by bindep? I think for all current ubuntus they are base-py3, not sure about suse or debian or alpine.

bindep.txt.message: why is this empty file needed?

Not really, I will remove it and eventually add it in another change.

The main reason for adding it is that bindep chokes if run in a folder without a bindep.txt file, so testing "bindep --platforms" in the root of it own repo didn't work.

In any case this would be a separate issue to address.

bindep/depends.py.message: Hasn't fedora been dnf since like 22? Not sure we need this switch for fedora
indeed, not a full bug because anything before 28 is already out of support anyway but I will fix it.
I thought RHEL 8 shipped with yum4, a wrapper to dnf. I am unsure if dnf command is actually present.
While 'yum' exists, it's basically a symlink to dnf. So they don't continue to behave the same.  man yum is basically dnf's man page.

The issue here is, RHEL 8 seems to default to yum as the package manager:

  https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8-beta/html/8.0_beta_release_notes/new-features#software_management_2

However, yum really is dnf here, with some magic sauce to keep backwards compat. So, I am unsure if we want to override the default to dnf for bindep.

Lets get ianw to review, he's been doing a lot of work on rhel8 and dib.

The purpose of this is to expose only the implicit/default package manager, not optional ones. Both yum and dnf coexisted for years but only one was official for a specific  distro-version combination.

[stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ cat /etc/redhat-release && ls -al /usr/bin/yum
Red Hat Enterprise Linux release 8.0 Beta (Ootpa)
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root 5 Oct 15 09:25 /usr/bin/yum -> dnf-3
I'm not sure I agree with the Ubuntu cutoff. Even on 18.04 the default "python" binary points to python2 for me.

Do not confuse what python executable points to with official python version. Due to some old PSF backed recommendation most py3 distros do not even have a python executable but they have "python3" installed.

The infamous document I am referring to is https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0394/

One less official way to test which is default/prefered way to install it to see what happens when you try to install tox package. On newer distros I found it to install python3.

On the other hand keep in mind that we never said that we would only publish one of base-py2 or base-py3, so it may be possible to expose both if we decide is better (without breaking dependencies)

bindep/tests/bindep.txt.message: The code says py2 is set for Fedora<23, not 28
Yep, 23 is correct. Not that I do expect to see users using  versions with these numbers. Still, good idea to be historically correct ;)
